WordPress Element Types

Blocks

Individual content elements (like text, images, or buttons) used to build a WordPress page or post, arranged directly within the block editor. These can range from a simple atomic element to custom blocks that could be a complex section layout.

Patterns

Pre-arranged and configured collections of blocks that can be inserted into a page or post to quickly create complex layouts, acting as reusable templates. Once a un-synced pattern has been added to a page, it loses any connect to the pattern. Updates to a pattern will not be applied to other instances. Patterns can exist as entries in the site's database or via code in a theme or plugin.

Synced patterns

Special patterns that, when updated in one place, will automatically update everywhere they're used across the site, ensuring consistency. Updates are applied to both content and layout or configuration changes. At this time, synced patterns can only exist in the database.

Synced patterns with overrides

Synced patterns that allow the content of specific child elements to be customized locally, while other instances remain synced across the site. The intention with synced overrides is to give the ability to use patterns or layout or design while overriding content. These patterns would follow the same rule that all changes would sync with the exception or any local overrides. At this time, synced patterns with overrides can only exist in the database.
